Margaret McLeod stared at the rejection letter from the Highland Wildlife Park, her third denial in as many weeks. The crisp Edinburgh letterhead seemed to mock her from across her cluttered desk at Henderson & Associates Chartered Accountants. Outside her office window, Glasgow's perpetual drizzle painted the city in shades of grey that matched her mood perfectly.

"Och, what's got you looking like someone's stolen your lunch money?" Her colleague David poked his head through the doorway, his tie askew as usual after another long morning wrestling with quarterly reports.

Margaret folded the letter carefully and slipped it into her handbag. "Nothing that concerns you, David. Don't you have the Morrison account to finish?"

David shrugged and disappeared back into the maze of cubicles and filing cabinets that comprised their floor of the building. Margaret had worked at Henderson & Associates for twelve years, climbing steadily from junior clerk to senior accountant, but lately the numbers on spreadsheets seemed to blur together into meaningless columns of mediocrity.

The idea had started three months ago during a particularly tedious audit. She'd been watching a nature documentary during her lunch break, something about tiger conservation in India, when she learned that private individuals could actually sponsor and even adopt big cats from accredited facilities. Not bring them home, of course, but provide funding for their care while participating in conservation efforts. It wasn't the sponsorship that caught her attention though—it was the mention that some facilities, under very specific circumstances, allowed qualified individuals to house rescued tigers on properly licensed private property.

That evening, Margaret had called her best friend Fiona MacBride with barely contained excitement. Fiona, a freelance journalist who'd known Margaret since their university days at Strathclyde, listened patiently as Margaret explained her sudden fascination with tiger adoption.

"You want to do what exactly?" Fiona had asked, her voice crackling through the mobile connection.

"I want to adopt a tiger, Fi. Not just sponsor one—actually provide a home for a rescued tiger. There are facilities that work with private individuals who have the proper setup and licensing."

There had been a long pause before Fiona responded. "Margaret, love, you live in a two-bedroom flat in Merchant City. Where exactly would you keep a tiger?"

"I'd need to buy property, obviously. Somewhere with space, proper fencing, the right permits. I've been doing research, and it's complicated but not impossible."

Margaret had spent weeks researching the legal requirements, the costs, the facilities needed. She'd discovered that while exotic pet ownership was heavily regulated in Scotland, it wasn't entirely prohibited for those willing to navigate the Byzantine web of licensing requirements from multiple government agencies. She'd need a Dangerous Wild Animals licence, proper insurance, veterinary connections, and most importantly, a partnership with an accredited conservation organization.

The rejections had started immediately. Every wildlife sanctuary, zoo, and conservation group she contacted responded with polite but firm refusals. Too risky, they said. Inappropriate for private ownership. Better to support their existing programs through traditional donations.

Margaret pulled out her mobile and scrolled through her contacts until she found Dr. James Hartwell's number. She'd discovered him through an online forum dedicated to exotic animal conservation—a veterinarian who'd worked extensively with big cats and had connections throughout the international conservation community. More importantly, he'd seemed genuinely interested when she'd first explained her proposal two weeks earlier.

"Dr. Hartwell? It's Margaret McLeod calling from Glasgow."

"Ms. McLeod, good to hear from you. I trust you received my email about the potential opportunity?"

Margaret's pulse quickened. She hadn't checked her email since arriving at the office that morning. "I'm sorry, I haven't had a chance to review it yet. Could you give me the details over the phone?"

"Certainly. I've been in contact with a facility in Romania—they rescue tigers from circuses and private owners throughout Eastern Europe. They have a young female, about three years old, who was confiscated from an illegal breeding operation. She's been rehabilitated but can't be released into the wild, obviously. The facility is overcrowded and looking for qualified private placements."

Margaret grabbed a pen and started scribbling notes on the back of an invoice. "What would be required?"

"Substantial property—at least five acres with proper enclosures built to international standards. Full licensing through DEFRA and Scottish Natural Heritage. Insurance coverage of at least two million pounds. And of course, ongoing veterinary care and feeding costs, which run approximately fifteen hundred pounds monthly."

The numbers swirled in Margaret's head. Her savings account held just over forty thousand pounds, nowhere near enough for property and the required infrastructure. But she'd been thinking about that problem for weeks now.

"Dr. Hartwell, if I could secure the financing and property, how quickly could this happen?"

"The facility needs a placement within six months. After that, they'll likely have to make other arrangements."

After ending the call, Margaret sat quietly in her office, listening to the familiar sounds of keyboard clicks and muffled telephone conversations that formed the soundtrack of her professional life. Six months to completely upend everything she'd built over the past decade. Six months to transform from a careful, methodical accountant into someone who kept a tiger in her backyard.

She opened her laptop and began composing an email to every bank in Glasgow.The email responses from the banks arrived with predictable uniformity over the following days. Polite rejections couched in financial jargon that all boiled down to the same message: no institution would provide a mortgage for property intended to house dangerous wildlife. Margaret printed each response and filed them methodically in a folder she'd labeled "Tiger Project - Finance," maintaining the same organizational habits that had served her well in accounting even as she ventured into increasingly uncharted territory.

By Thursday evening, she found herself sitting across from Fiona at their usual corner table in The Finnieston, picking at fish and chips while her friend studied the printed bank responses with the same intensity she typically reserved for investigative articles. Fiona had always been the more adventurous of the two, spending her career chasing stories across Europe and occasionally further afield, but even she seemed taken aback by the scope of Margaret's ambitions.

"You're serious about this, aren't you?" Fiona asked, setting down the last rejection letter from Royal Bank of Scotland. "I mean, properly serious, not just having a midlife crisis that involves watching too many nature documentaries."

Margaret pushed a chip around her plate, considering how to explain the intensity of feeling that had been building over the past months. It wasn't just about the tiger, though she couldn't deny the appeal of providing a home for an animal that needed one. There was something else, something harder to articulate about the profound dissatisfaction that had been growing in her chest like a physical weight every morning when she walked into the Henderson & Associates building.

"Do you remember when we were at university, how we used to talk about the lives we'd lead? You were going to be this fearless journalist uncovering corruption and writing about conflicts, and I was going to travel the world working for some international organization, maybe UNESCO or something similar." Margaret finally looked up from her plate to meet Fiona's concerned gaze. "You actually did it, Fi. You became exactly who you said you'd become. But I got comfortable, got scared, got practical. I've spent twelve years adding up other people's numbers and filing other people's paperwork, and I can feel myself disappearing into it."

Fiona reached across the table and squeezed Margaret's hand. "There's nothing wrong with stability, love. You've got a good job, a nice flat, savings in the bank. That's more than a lot of people can say, especially in this economy."

"But what if I don't want stability anymore? What if I want to do something completely mad and impractical and important?" Margaret pulled her hand back and leaned forward, her voice gaining intensity. "This tiger, she's real, Fi. She's sitting in some overcrowded facility in Romania right now, and in six months they're going to have to make 'other arrangements' if no one steps forward. I could be the person who steps forward."

The conversation was interrupted by Margaret's mobile buzzing insistently against the wooden table. She glanced at the screen and saw her brother's name, then let it go to voicemail. Robert called precisely once per week, usually on Thursday evenings, to check in with his customary blend of brotherly concern and subtle condescension. Tonight she wasn't in the mood for his well-meaning advice about being more social or his not-so-subtle hints that she should consider settling down before it was "too late."

"That'll be Robert," she explained to Fiona. "I'll call him back tomorrow."

Fiona raised an eyebrow. "Have you mentioned your tiger plan to your dear brother yet?"

"God, no. He'd probably stage some sort of intervention. You know how he gets about anything that doesn't fit into his neat little boxes of appropriate behavior." Margaret signaled the server for another pint. "He's been trying to set me up with his colleague from the law firm for months. Apparently Alan is 'very stable' and 'ready to settle down.' The last thing Robert wants to hear is that his spinster sister is planning to liquidate her life savings to house a dangerous predator."

They spent the rest of the evening discussing more practical matters - Fiona's latest article about housing developments along the Clyde, Margaret's ongoing battle with her building's management company over heating issues, the usual comfortable territory of friendship that didn't require life-altering decisions. But as they parted ways outside the restaurant, Fiona grabbed Margaret's arm with sudden intensity.

"If you're really going to do this thing, you need to stop thinking like an accountant and start thinking like an entrepreneur. Banks won't fund your dream, but that doesn't mean it's impossible. There are other ways to raise money, other sources of funding. You just need to get creative."

Margaret walked home through the Glasgow drizzle, Fiona's words echoing in her mind. Other ways to raise money. She'd been approaching this like a traditional business loan, presenting herself as a reliable employee seeking to purchase property. But what if she approached it differently? What if instead of asking banks to fund her personal dream, she created something bigger, something that could attract investors or grants or partnerships?

Back in her flat, she ignored the blinking light on her answering machine indicating Robert's message and instead opened her laptop. She began researching conservation grants, private foundations that funded wildlife preservation, crowdfunding platforms that specialized in environmental causes. The deeper she dug into the world of conservation funding, the more possibilities emerged. There were organizations that provided grants for private individuals undertaking conservation work, foundations established by wealthy environmentalists looking to support innovative projects, even government programs designed to encourage private participation in species preservation.

By two in the morning, Margaret had filled three pages of her notebook with contact information, application deadlines, and eligibility requirements. Her eyes burned from staring at the screen, but for the first time in months she felt the electric satisfaction of a problem that might actually have solutions. She wasn't just Margaret McLeod, senior accountant, anymore. She was Margaret McLeod, potential conservationist, future tiger guardian, woman who might actually pull off something extraordinary.Her mobile rang at precisely seven-thirty the next morning, and Margaret knew without looking that it would be Robert. Her brother maintained the same rigid schedule he'd followed since law school, arriving at his office by eight sharp and dealing with personal calls before the business day officially began. Margaret considered letting it ring through to voicemail again, but the persistence of the sound in her small flat finally drove her to answer.

"You're avoiding me," Robert said without preamble, his voice carrying that particular blend of hurt and accusation that only siblings could perfect. "I called last night and you didn't ring back. That's not like you, Margaret."

Margaret padded to her kitchen and began the familiar ritual of morning coffee preparation, cradling the phone between her shoulder and ear. Through her window, Glasgow was waking up to another grey morning, the streets already busy with commuters hurrying toward the city center. "I was out with Fiona, and by the time I got home it was too late to call. You know how you get about being disturbed after nine."

"Fair enough, but you sound different. Distracted. Is everything alright at work? Henderson isn't making redundancies again, is he?" Robert's concern was genuine, which made Margaret feel guilty about the conversation she was inevitably going to have to have with him. Her brother had spent years worrying about her contentment, or lack thereof, and she knew that her latest plan would confirm his worst fears about her decision-making capabilities.

Margaret poured hot water over coffee grounds and watched them bloom in the French press, buying herself a few moments to consider how much to reveal. Robert was fundamentally conservative in his worldview, a successful solicitor who believed in measured decisions, careful planning, and above all, reasonable behavior. The idea of his sister liquidating her savings to house a tiger would strike him as evidence of some sort of psychological breakdown.

"Work is fine, Robert. Actually, I've been thinking about making some changes in my life. Maybe it's time I did something different, something more meaningful." She pressed down on the coffee plunger with more force than necessary, watching the dark liquid rise through the metal filter.

There was a pause on the other end of the line, and Margaret could practically hear her brother's mental calculations clicking into place. Robert approached conversations the same way he approached legal briefs, gathering evidence and building toward conclusions with methodical precision. "What sort of changes are we talking about? Please tell me you're not thinking of chucking in your job to become a pottery instructor or something equally impractical."

Despite everything, Margaret found herself smiling at her brother's predictability. Robert had been making jokes about middle-aged career changes ever since his law partner's wife had left her position at a bank to open an art gallery that promptly failed within eighteen months. "Not pottery, no. But you're not entirely wrong about the impractical part."

"Margaret, you're making me nervous. Just tell me straight - what's this about?" Robert's voice had shifted into what Margaret recognized as his professional mode, the tone he used when preparing clients for difficult news.

Margaret took a long sip of coffee and made a decision that would prove to be either liberating or catastrophic. "I'm planning to adopt a tiger, Robert. Not sponsor one or donate to a zoo - actually provide a home for a rescued tiger that needs placement. I've been researching it for months, and I've found a facility in Romania with a young female who needs rehoming within six months."

The silence that followed was so complete that Margaret wondered if the call had been dropped. She checked her phone screen to confirm they were still connected, then waited through what felt like the longest pause in the history of sibling communication. When Robert finally spoke, his voice had dropped to the careful, measured tone he used when dealing with clients who might be having mental health crises.

"Margaret, I think perhaps you should take some time off work. Maybe see someone to talk through whatever's been bothering you. This tiger idea, it's not rational. You live in a flat in the city center. You work in accounting. You don't know anything about caring for exotic animals." Robert's words came slowly, as if he were speaking to someone who might bolt at any sudden movement.

Margaret had anticipated this reaction, but hearing it articulated so clearly still stung. This was exactly why she'd avoided telling him - not because she thought he was wrong, but because she knew he was probably right, and she was determined to do it anyway. "I know it sounds mad, Robert, but I've done the research. It's legal with the proper licensing, and there are veterinarians who specialize in big cat care. I'd need to buy property outside the city, build proper enclosures, get insurance and permits. It's complicated but not impossible."

"Have you considered the cost? We're talking about hundreds of thousands of pounds, Margaret. Property, construction, ongoing care, insurance, licensing fees - and that's assuming you could even get approved, which is highly unlikely." Robert was warming to his argument now, marshaling facts the way he would challenge a witness in court. "And what happens when the tiger gets older, stronger, more dangerous? What happens if there's an accident, if someone gets hurt? You'd lose everything, face criminal charges, potentially worse."

Margaret stood at her kitchen window, watching office workers stream past on the pavement below, all of them heading toward jobs that provided steady paychecks and predictable futures. Six months ago, she would have been getting ready to join them, to spend another day adding columns of numbers and filing reports that no one would remember a week later. The tiger plan was insane, expensive, and probably doomed to failure, but it was also the first thing that had made her feel genuinely excited about getting up in the morning since she couldn't remember when.

"I might fail, Robert. I probably will fail. But I'm going to try anyway, because the alternative is spending the rest of my life wondering what would have happened if I'd been brave enough to attempt something extraordinary." Margaret surprised herself with the firmness in her voice, the absence of the apologetic tone she usually adopted when explaining her decisions to her brother.

Robert sighed heavily, and Margaret could picture him in his pristine office, straightening papers on his desk while contemplating how to handle his sister's apparent midlife crisis. "At least promise me you'll think this through properly. Don't make any irreversible decisions without talking to me first. Maybe we could meet for dinner this weekend and discuss the practical aspects more thoroughly."

Margaret agreed to dinner, knowing that Robert would spend the intervening days preparing arguments designed to talk her out of what he would undoubtedly characterize as temporary insanity. After ending the call, she finished her coffee and began getting ready for another day at Henderson & Associates, but her mind was already racing ahead to the evening's tasks. She had grant applications to complete, conservation organizations to contact, and property listings to research. For the first time in years, the prospect of leaving her flat felt like the beginning of an adventure rather than another step in an endless routine.**Chapter 2**

The Mackintosh Foundation occupied a restored Victorian townhouse in Edinburgh's New Town, its Georgian facades and manicured gardens suggesting the sort of old money philanthropy that Margaret had only read about in financial journals. She stood outside the wrought-iron gates at precisely ten minutes before her appointment, clutching a leather portfolio that contained what she hoped would be the most persuasive presentation of her life. Three weeks had passed since her conversation with Robert, three weeks of fevered preparation that had transformed her evening hours into a crash course in conservation biology, animal husbandry, and grant writing. Her brother had maintained a worried silence since their dinner the previous weekend, where his carefully prepared arguments had met with Margaret's equally carefully prepared responses, resulting in a stalemate that left both siblings frustrated and concerned.

Margaret had discovered the Mackintosh Foundation through a contact at the Scottish Wildlife Trust, a elderly volunteer named Mrs. Sinclair who had listened to Margaret's proposal with the kind of patient attention usually reserved for favorite grandchildren. The foundation, Mrs. Sinclair had explained, was established in the 1970s by Sir Duncan Mackintosh, a shipping magnate who had developed a passion for wildlife conservation after witnessing the destruction of tiger habitats during business trips to Southeast Asia. Since his death fifteen years ago, the foundation had been run by his daughter, Dr. Catherine Mackintosh, a former veterinarian who had abandoned private practice to focus on conservation work. More importantly, the foundation had a history of funding unconventional projects, including several private conservation efforts that traditional organizations had deemed too risky or innovative.

The receptionist, a young man with carefully styled hair and the sort of earnest demeanor that suggested recent university graduation, led Margaret through corridors lined with photographs of exotic wildlife and framed letters from conservation organizations around the world. Dr. Mackintosh's office occupied the entire top floor of the building, its tall windows offering panoramic views of Edinburgh's skyline while the walls displayed an eclectic collection of artifacts that spoke to a life spent traveling in service of wildlife preservation. Carved masks from Africa shared wall space with traditional textiles from India, while a massive mahogany desk was covered with reports, correspondence, and what appeared to be veterinary journals dating back several decades.

Dr. Catherine Mackintosh proved to be a woman in her early sixties with steel-grey hair pulled back in a practical bun and the sort of direct gaze that Margaret associated with people accustomed to making difficult decisions. She wore no makeup and minimal jewelry, but carried herself with the confidence of someone who had earned respect through competence rather than charm. When she spoke, her voice carried the slight Edinburgh accent of the educated classes, tempered by years of international travel and cross-cultural communication.

"Mrs. McLeod, I've read your preliminary proposal with considerable interest," Dr. Mackintosh began, gesturing for Margaret to take a seat in one of the leather chairs positioned in front of her desk. "I must admit, it's been some time since we received an application quite so ambitious from someone with so little direct experience in wildlife management. Tell me, what makes you believe you're qualified to provide appropriate care for a tiger?"

Margaret had anticipated this question and had prepared for it extensively, but sitting in Dr. Mackintosh's office surrounded by evidence of decades of professional conservation work, her carefully rehearsed answer suddenly felt inadequate. She opened her portfolio and withdrew a thick folder containing certificates from every online course in exotic animal care she had completed over the past month, letters from veterinarians expressing willingness to provide consultation, and detailed architectural plans for enclosure construction that had cost her nearly a thousand pounds to commission.

"Dr. Mackintosh, I won't pretend to have the sort of hands-on experience that traditional applicants might possess, but I believe I bring something equally valuable - a commitment to learning everything necessary to provide exceptional care, and the financial and organizational skills to ensure the project's long-term sustainability." Margaret spread the documents across the coffee table between them, her accountant's instincts taking over as she began presenting her case with the same methodical precision she brought to complex audits. "I've completed intensive courses in big cat nutrition, enclosure design, and emergency veterinary care. I've established relationships with three veterinary practices that specialize in exotic animals, including Dr. James Hartwell, who has twenty years of experience with tigers specifically."

Dr. Mackintosh examined the certificates and correspondence with the careful attention of someone accustomed to evaluating proposals for their feasibility rather than their good intentions. She asked detailed questions about feeding schedules, enrichment activities, emergency protocols, and backup care arrangements that demonstrated both her expertise and her skepticism about Margaret's preparedness for the realities of tiger guardianship. Margaret found herself defending decisions she had made during late-night research sessions, explaining cost calculations she had performed using the same analytical skills that made her valuable to Henderson & Associates.

"The financial projections are thorough," Dr. Mackintosh finally conceded, setting aside Margaret's spreadsheets after nearly twenty minutes of detailed examination. "You've clearly invested considerable time in understanding the practical requirements. But caring for a tiger isn't simply a matter of providing adequate food and shelter, Mrs. McLeod. These animals require constant attention, sophisticated environmental enrichment, and above all, respect for their fundamental wildness. Even rescued tigers that can never be released retain their predatory instincts and territorial behaviors. Are you prepared for the reality that this animal will never be a pet, will never demonstrate affection or gratitude, and could seriously injure or kill you if proper protocols aren't maintained?"

Margaret had watched enough wildlife documentaries and read enough case studies to understand the dangers intellectually, but Dr. Mackintosh's words carried the weight of direct experience with people who had underestimated the challenges of exotic animal care. She thought about her comfortable flat in Merchant City, her predictable routine at the accounting firm, the safety and security she was preparing to abandon in favor of sharing her property with an apex predator. The rational part of her mind, the part that had guided her through twelve years of careful financial planning and professional advancement, screamed warnings about the magnitude of the risk she was contemplating.

"Dr. Mackintosh, I understand that this tiger will never be domesticated, and I'm not seeking a pet or companion. What I'm offering is a permanent sanctuary for an animal that needs one, maintained by someone who has the resources and commitment to provide appropriate care for the duration of her natural life." Margaret leaned forward, abandoning her prepared talking points in favor of the honest emotion that had been driving her for months. "I know this sounds presumptuous coming from someone who has never been closer to a tiger than the Glasgow Zoo, but I believe I can provide something that overcrowded facilities and understaffed sanctuaries cannot - individualized attention, unlimited resources, and a guarantee that this specific animal will never be abandoned or euthanized due to financial constraints."

Dr. Mackintosh stood and moved to one of the tall windows, gazing out at Edinburgh's ancient skyline while considering Margaret's words. The silence stretched long enough for Margaret to notice the distant sound of traffic and the rhythmic ticking of an antique clock on the mantelpiece. When Dr. Mackintosh finally turned back toward her, her expression had shifted from professional skepticism to something that might have been cautious interest.

"The Mackintosh Foundation has supported private conservation efforts before, Mrs. McLeod, but never quite like what you're proposing. Our typical approach involves partnerships with established organizations, proven methodologies, measurable outcomes that contribute to broader conservation goals." Dr. Mackintosh returned to her desk and opened a thick file that Margaret realized must contain her application and supporting materials. "What you're suggesting is essentially a private sanctuary for a single animal, which raises questions about cost-effectiveness and conservation impact that our board would certainly want addressed."

Margaret felt her carefully constructed optimism beginning to crumble as Dr. Mackintosh articulated the practical objections that she had tried to ignore during her weeks of preparation. How could she justify the enormous expense of caring for one tiger when the same resources could support conservation efforts that might benefit dozens of animals or preserve critical habitats? How could she convince a professional foundation to fund what amounted to an elaborate personal project disguised as conservation work?

But before Margaret could formulate a response, Dr. Mackintosh continued in a tone that suggested she might not be entirely opposed to unconventional approaches. "However, there is something to be said for demonstrating that private individuals can successfully participate in conservation efforts at this level. If your project succeeded, it might encourage others to consider similar commitments, potentially creating a network of private sanctuaries that could provide placement opportunities for rescued animals." Dr. Mackintosh pulled out a legal pad and began making notes with the sort of rapid handwriting that suggested years of clinical practice. "The foundation's board meets monthly, and I believe your proposal deserves serious consideration, but you would need to address several concerns before I could recommend funding approval."

Margaret's pulse quickened as she realized that Dr. Mackintosh was not rejecting her application outright, but rather identifying obstacles that might potentially be overcome with proper preparation. She pulled out her notebook and prepared to document whatever requirements or modifications might make her proposal viable, feeling the same focused intensity that overtook her when solving complex accounting problems for demanding clients.

"First, you would need to demonstrate partnerships with established conservation organizations that could provide ongoing guidance and support. The foundation cannot fund isolated private efforts, regardless of their good intentions." Dr. Mackintosh continued making notes while she spoke, her clinical training evident in her systematic approach to problem-solving. "Second, you would need to establish clear educational and research components that would contribute to broader conservation knowledge. Simply providing excellent care for one animal, while admirable, doesn't meet our funding criteria for measurable conservation impact."

Margaret scribbled notes as quickly as Dr. Mackintosh spoke, already beginning to envision modifications to her proposal that might address these requirements. Educational components could include school visits, veterinary student internships, documentation of care protocols that might be shared with other facilities. Research opportunities might involve behavioral studies, nutrition trials, enrichment effectiveness measurements that could contribute to improved care standards at other sanctuaries and zoos.

"Finally, you would need to demonstrate absolute financial sustainability beyond our initial funding period. The foundation typically provides seed funding for conservation projects, not ongoing operational support." Dr. Mackintosh set down her pen and looked directly at Margaret with the sort of intense focus that made it clear this final requirement was non-negotiable. "A tiger can live twenty years or more in captivity, Mrs. McLeod. Can you guarantee that you will be able to provide appropriate care, veterinary treatment, and facility maintenance for the entire duration of this animal's natural life, regardless of changes in your personal circumstances, health, or financial situation?"

The question hung in the air between them, and Margaret realized that Dr. Mackintosh was asking her to make a commitment that would define the rest of her life. Twenty years of monthly feeding costs, veterinary bills, insurance premiums, facility repairs, and regulatory compliance. Twenty years during which she could never take extended vacations, could never move house casually, could never make major life decisions without considering their impact on a tiger's wellbeing. Twenty years of responsibility for a creature that could kill her if she made a serious mistake, but would depend entirely on her competence and dedication for survival.

Margaret thought about her savings account, her steady job, her comfortable flat, all the security she had built through years of careful planning and conservative choices. Then she thought about the tiger in Romania, waiting in an overcrowded facility for someone to offer her a permanent home, and about her own life, stretching ahead in an endless succession of quarterly reports and audit preparations that would leave no mark on the world beyond a series of balanced spreadsheets.

"Dr. Mackintosh, I can make that commitment," Margaret said, surprised by the steadiness of her own voice. "I understand the magnitude of what I'm promising, and I'm prepared to restructure my entire life around this responsibility."

Dr. Mackintosh studied Margaret's face with the intensity of someone accustomed to evaluating the reliability of people making ambitious promises, then nodded slowly and made a final note in her file. "Very well, Mrs. McLeod. I'm willing to present your proposal to our board, provided you can address the partnership and educational requirements within the next six weeks. The foundation's next meeting is scheduled for early December, which would allow for funding decisions to be made before your six-month deadline with the Romanian facility."

As Margaret gathered her documents and prepared to leave Dr. Mackintosh's office, she felt the exhilarating terror of someone who had just committed to jumping off a cliff while still figuring out whether her parachute would deploy properly. Six weeks to transform her personal dream into a legitimate conservation project, to establish partnerships with organizations that had never heard of her, to design educational programs for an audience she had never taught. Six weeks to prove that Margaret McLeod, senior accountant, could become Margaret McLeod, wildlife conservationist, before her opportunity disappeared forever.**Chapter 3**

Margaret's transformation from cautious accountant to aspiring conservationist accelerated dramatically following her meeting with Dr. Mackintosh. The six-week deadline loomed with the sort of urgent intensity that she typically associated with tax season, but instead of reconciling corporate accounts, she found herself navigating the labyrinthine world of wildlife conservation partnerships. Her evenings, once devoted to quiet dinners and television programs, became frantic sessions of email correspondence with zoo directors, sanctuary managers, and academic researchers across Scotland and beyond. Her small dining table disappeared under stacks of conservation journals, partnership agreements, and hastily printed research proposals, transforming her orderly flat into something resembling a campaign headquarters for an impossibly ambitious political candidate.

The first breakthrough came through Dr. Hartwell, whose connections in the veterinary community provided Margaret with an introduction to Dr. Sarah Chen at the University of Edinburgh's School of Biological Sciences. Dr. Chen, a behavioral ecologist specializing in large carnivore psychology, had spent the better part of her academic career studying captive tiger behavior and had long advocated for more innovative approaches to wildlife conservation that incorporated private sector participation. When Margaret explained her proposal during a coffee meeting near the university campus, Dr. Chen's initial skepticism gradually gave way to genuine interest as she recognized the research opportunities that a privately funded, single-animal facility might provide.

"The problem with most captive tiger research is that we're studying animals in environments that prioritize public education and entertainment over natural behavior expression," Dr. Chen explained, stirring sugar into her cappuccino while Margaret frantically took notes in the margins of her ever-present notebook. "Zoos have dozens of species to manage, limited space, constant visitor traffic, and budget constraints that prevent them from creating truly optimal environments for individual animals. What you're proposing could serve as a model for ideal captive tiger care, assuming you're willing to participate in rigorous behavioral documentation and environmental optimization studies."

Margaret found herself agreeing to research protocols she barely understood, committing to data collection procedures that would require her to become a amateur ethologist in addition to her other rapidly expanding skill sets. Dr. Chen outlined a potential partnership that would involve university graduate students conducting thesis research at Margaret's facility, behavioral assessments that could inform care improvements at other institutions, and publication of findings that might influence captive tiger management practices internationally. The conversation lasted nearly three hours and concluded with Dr. Chen agreeing to co-author a formal partnership proposal that could be submitted to both the Mackintosh Foundation and the university's research ethics committee.

Meanwhile, Margaret's relationship with her colleagues at Henderson & Associates had begun to deteriorate as her distraction became increasingly obvious to everyone around her. David, who had initially dismissed her unusual behavior as temporary stress, started making pointed comments about her frequent personal phone calls and her tendency to stare out the window during meetings with clients. Mr. Henderson himself, a man in his seventies who had built his practice on the principle that accountants should be invisible and reliable, called Margaret into his office on a Thursday afternoon with the sort of grave expression typically reserved for discussions about embezzlement or gross negligence.

"Margaret, you've been with us for twelve years, and I've always considered you one of our most dependable senior staff members," Mr. Henderson began, settling his considerable bulk into the leather chair behind his mahogany desk while Margaret perched nervously on the edge of the visitor chair she had occupied countless times during performance reviews and client debriefings. "However, several clients have mentioned that you seem distracted during meetings, and I've noticed that your billable hours have declined significantly over the past month. Is there something happening in your personal life that's affecting your professional performance?"

Margaret realized that she had arrived at a crossroads that she had been unconsciously avoiding for weeks. She could apologize, refocus her attention on her accounting responsibilities, and continue collecting her steady salary while pursuing her tiger project as an evening hobby that might or might not result in anything concrete. Alternatively, she could acknowledge what had already become obvious to everyone around her - that her heart was no longer in the work that had defined her adult identity, and that she was already mentally preparing for a completely different kind of life. The choice felt simultaneously terrifying and liberating, like standing at the edge of a high diving board while a crowd of spectators waited to see whether she would jump or climb back down the ladder.

"Mr. Henderson, I appreciate your concern and your patience over the past month. You're absolutely right that I've been distracted, and I think it's only fair to tell you that I'm considering a significant career change that would require me to leave Henderson & Associates." Margaret surprised herself with the calm firmness of her voice, as if some decisive part of her personality had finally taken control of the conversation. "I've been developing a wildlife conservation project that would require my full attention, and while I haven't made final decisions about timing, I wanted to give you as much notice as possible."

Margaret McLeod stared at the rejection letter from the Highland Wildlife Park, her third denial in as many weeks. The crisp Edinburgh letterhead seemed to mock her from across her cluttered desk at Henderson & Associates Chartered Accountants. Outside her office window, Glasgow's perpetual drizzle painted the city in shades of grey that matched her mood perfectly.

"Och, what's got you looking like someone's stolen your lunch money?" Her colleague David poked his head through the doorway, his tie askew as usual after another long morning wrestling with quarterly reports.

Margaret folded the letter carefully and slipped it into her handbag. "Nothing that concerns you, David. Don't you have the Morrison account to finish?"

David shrugged and disappeared back into the maze of cubicles and filing cabinets that comprised their floor of the building. Margaret had worked at Henderson & Associates for twelve years, climbing steadily from junior clerk to senior accountant, but lately the numbers on spreadsheets seemed to blur together into meaningless columns of mediocrity.

The idea had started three months ago during a particularly tedious audit. She'd been watching a nature documentary during her lunch break, something about tiger conservation in India, when she learned that private individuals could actually sponsor and even adopt big cats from accredited facilities. Not bring them home, of course, but provide funding for their care while participating in conservation efforts. It wasn't the sponsorship that caught her attention though—it was the mention that some facilities, under very specific circumstances, allowed qualified individuals to house rescued tigers on properly licensed private property.

That evening, Margaret had called her best friend Fiona MacBride with barely contained excitement. Fiona, a freelance journalist who'd known Margaret since their university days at Strathclyde, listened patiently as Margaret explained her sudden fascination with tiger adoption.

"You want to do what exactly?" Fiona had asked, her voice crackling through the mobile connection.

"I want to adopt a tiger, Fi. Not just sponsor one—actually provide a home for a rescued tiger. There are facilities that work with private individuals who have the proper setup and licensing."

There had been a long pause before Fiona responded. "Margaret, love, you live in a two-bedroom flat in Merchant City. Where exactly would you keep a tiger?"

"I'd need to buy property, obviously. Somewhere with space, proper fencing, the right permits. I've been doing research, and it's complicated but not impossible."

Margaret had spent weeks researching the legal requirements, the costs, the facilities needed. She'd discovered that while exotic pet ownership was heavily regulated in Scotland, it wasn't entirely prohibited for those willing to navigate the Byzantine web of licensing requirements from multiple government agencies. She'd need a Dangerous Wild Animals licence, proper insurance, veterinary connections, and most importantly, a partnership with an accredited conservation organization.

The rejections had started immediately. Every wildlife sanctuary, zoo, and conservation group she contacted responded with polite but firm refusals. Too risky, they said. Inappropriate for private ownership. Better to support their existing programs through traditional donations.

Margaret pulled out her mobile and scrolled through her contacts until she found Dr. James Hartwell's number. She'd discovered him through an online forum dedicated to exotic animal conservation—a veterinarian who'd worked extensively with big cats and had connections throughout the international conservation community. More importantly, he'd seemed genuinely interested when she'd first explained her proposal two weeks earlier.

"Dr. Hartwell? It's Margaret McLeod calling from Glasgow."

"Ms. McLeod, good to hear from you. I trust you received my email about the potential opportunity?"

Margaret's pulse quickened. She hadn't checked her email since arriving at the office that morning. "I'm sorry, I haven't had a chance to review it yet. Could you give me the details over the phone?"

"Certainly. I've been in contact with a facility in Romania—they rescue tigers from circuses and private owners throughout Eastern Europe. They have a young female, about three years old, who was confiscated from an illegal breeding operation. She's been rehabilitated but can't be released into the wild, obviously. The facility is overcrowded and looking for qualified private placements."

Margaret grabbed a pen and started scribbling notes on the back of an invoice. "What would be required?"

"Substantial property—at least five acres with proper enclosures built to international standards. Full licensing through DEFRA and Scottish Natural Heritage. Insurance coverage of at least two million pounds. And of course, ongoing veterinary care and feeding costs, which run approximately fifteen hundred pounds monthly."

The numbers swirled in Margaret's head. Her savings account held just over forty thousand pounds, nowhere near enough for property and the required infrastructure. But she'd been thinking about that problem for weeks now.

"Dr. Hartwell, if I could secure the financing and property, how quickly could this happen?"

"The facility needs a placement within six months. After that, they'll likely have to make other arrangements."

After ending the call, Margaret sat quietly in her office, listening to the familiar sounds of keyboard clicks and muffled telephone conversations that formed the soundtrack of her professional life. Six months to completely upend everything she'd built over the past decade. Six months to transform from a careful, methodical accountant into someone who kept a tiger in her backyard.

She opened her laptop and began composing an email to every bank in Glasgow.

The email responses from the banks arrived with predictable uniformity over the following days. Polite rejections couched in financial jargon that all boiled down to the same message: no institution would provide a mortgage for property intended to house dangerous wildlife. Margaret printed each response and filed them methodically in a folder she'd labeled "Tiger Project - Finance," maintaining the same organizational habits that had served her well in accounting even as she ventured into increasingly uncharted territory.

By Thursday evening, she found herself sitting across from Fiona at their usual corner table in The Finnieston, picking at fish and chips while her friend studied the printed bank responses with the same intensity she typically reserved for investigative articles. Fiona had always been the more adventurous of the two, spending her career chasing stories across Europe and occasionally further afield, but even she seemed taken aback by the scope of Margaret's ambitions.

"You're serious about this, aren't you?" Fiona asked, setting down the last rejection letter from Royal Bank of Scotland. "I mean, properly serious, not just having a midlife crisis that involves watching too many nature documentaries."

Margaret pushed a chip around her plate, considering how to explain the intensity of feeling that had been building over the past months. It wasn't just about the tiger, though she couldn't deny the appeal of providing a home for an animal that needed one. There was something else, something harder to articulate about the profound dissatisfaction that had been growing in her chest like a physical weight every morning when she walked into the Henderson & Associates building.

"Do you remember when we were at university, how we used to talk about the lives we'd lead? You were going to be this fearless journalist uncovering corruption and writing about conflicts, and I was going to travel the world working for some international organization, maybe UNESCO or something similar." Margaret finally looked up from her plate to meet Fiona's concerned gaze. "You actually did it, Fi. You became exactly who you said you'd become. But I got comfortable, got scared, got practical. I've spent twelve years adding up other people's numbers and filing other people's paperwork, and I can feel myself disappearing into it."

Fiona reached across the table and squeezed Margaret's hand. "There's nothing wrong with stability, love. You've got a good job, a nice flat, savings in the bank. That's more than a lot of people can say, especially in this economy."

"But what if I don't want stability anymore? What if I want to do something completely mad and impractical and important?" Margaret pulled her hand back and leaned forward, her voice gaining intensity. "This tiger, she's real, Fi. She's sitting in some overcrowded facility in Romania right now, and in six months they're going to have to make 'other arrangements' if no one steps forward. I could be the person who steps forward."

The conversation was interrupted by Margaret's mobile buzzing insistently against the wooden table. She glanced at the screen and saw her brother's name, then let it go to voicemail. Robert called precisely once per week, usually on Thursday evenings, to check in with his customary blend of brotherly concern and subtle condescension. Tonight she wasn't in the mood for his well-meaning advice about being more social or his not-so-subtle hints that she should consider settling down before it was "too late."

"That'll be Robert," she explained to Fiona. "I'll call him back tomorrow."

Fiona raised an eyebrow. "Have you mentioned your tiger plan to your dear brother yet?"

"God, no. He'd probably stage some sort of intervention. You know how he gets about anything that doesn't fit into his neat little boxes of appropriate behavior." Margaret signaled the server for another pint. "He's been trying to set me up with his colleague from the law firm for months. Apparently Alan is 'very stable' and 'ready to settle down.' The last thing Robert wants to hear is that his spinster sister is planning to liquidate her life savings to house a dangerous predator."

They spent the rest of the evening discussing more practical matters - Fiona's latest article about housing developments along the Clyde, Margaret's ongoing battle with her building's management company over heating issues, the usual comfortable territory of friendship that didn't require life-altering decisions. But as they parted ways outside the restaurant, Fiona grabbed Margaret's arm with sudden intensity.

"If you're really going to do this thing, you need to stop thinking like an accountant and start thinking like an entrepreneur. Banks won't fund your dream, but that doesn't mean it's impossible. There are other ways to raise money, other sources of funding. You just need to get creative."

Margaret walked home through the Glasgow drizzle, Fiona's words echoing in her mind. Other ways to raise money. She'd been approaching this like a traditional business loan, presenting herself as a reliable employee seeking to purchase property. But what if she approached it differently? What if instead of asking banks to fund her personal dream, she created something bigger, something that could attract investors or grants or partnerships?

Back in her flat, she ignored the blinking light on her answering machine indicating Robert's message and instead opened her laptop. She began researching conservation grants, private foundations that funded wildlife preservation, crowdfunding platforms that specialized in environmental causes. The deeper she dug into the world of conservation funding, the more possibilities emerged. There were organizations that provided grants for private individuals undertaking conservation work, foundations established by wealthy environmentalists looking to support innovative projects, even government programs designed to encourage private participation in species preservation.

By two in the morning, Margaret had filled three pages of her notebook with contact information, application deadlines, and eligibility requirements. Her eyes burned from staring at the screen, but for the first time in months she felt the electric satisfaction of a problem that might actually have solutions. She wasn't just Margaret McLeod, senior accountant, anymore. She was Margaret McLeod, potential conservationist, future tiger guardian, woman who might actually pull off something extraordinary.

Her mobile rang at precisely seven-thirty the next morning, and Margaret knew without looking that it would be Robert. Her brother maintained the same rigid schedule he'd followed since law school, arriving at his office by eight sharp and dealing with personal calls before the business day officially began. Margaret considered letting it ring through to voicemail again, but the persistence of the sound in her small flat finally drove her to answer.

"You're avoiding me," Robert said without preamble, his voice carrying that particular blend of hurt and accusation that only siblings could perfect. "I called last night and you didn't ring back. That's not like you, Margaret."

Margaret padded to her kitchen and began the familiar ritual of morning coffee preparation, cradling the phone between her shoulder and ear. Through her window, Glasgow was waking up to another grey morning, the streets already busy with commuters hurrying toward the city center. "I was out with Fiona, and by the time I got home it was too late to call. You know how you get about being disturbed after nine."

"Fair enough, but you sound different. Distracted. Is everything alright at work? Henderson isn't making redundancies again, is he?" Robert's concern was genuine, which made Margaret feel guilty about the conversation she was inevitably going to have to have with him. Her brother had spent years worrying about her contentment, or lack thereof, and she knew that her latest plan would confirm his worst fears about her decision-making capabilities.

Margaret poured hot water over coffee grounds and watched them bloom in the French press, buying herself a few moments to consider how much to reveal. Robert was fundamentally conservative in his worldview, a successful solicitor who believed in measured decisions, careful planning, and above all, reasonable behavior. The idea of his sister liquidating her savings to house a tiger would strike him as evidence of some sort of psychological breakdown.

"Work is fine, Robert. Actually, I've been thinking about making some changes in my life. Maybe it's time I did something different, something more meaningful." She pressed down on the coffee plunger with more force than necessary, watching the dark liquid rise through the metal filter.

There was a pause on the other end of the line, and Margaret could practically hear her brother's mental calculations clicking into place. Robert approached conversations the same way he approached legal briefs, gathering evidence and building toward conclusions with methodical precision. "What sort of changes are we talking about? Please tell me you're not thinking of chucking in your job to become a pottery instructor or something equally impractical."

Despite everything, Margaret found herself smiling at her brother's predictability. Robert had been making jokes about middle-aged career changes ever since his law partner's wife had left her position at a bank to open an art gallery that promptly failed within eighteen months. "Not pottery, no. But you're not entirely wrong about the impractical part."

"Margaret, you're making me nervous. Just tell me straight - what's this about?" Robert's voice had shifted into what Margaret recognized as his professional mode, the tone he used when preparing clients for difficult news.

Margaret took a long sip of coffee and made a decision that would prove to be either liberating or catastrophic. "I'm planning to adopt a tiger, Robert. Not sponsor one or donate to a zoo - actually provide a home for a rescued tiger that needs placement. I've been researching it for months, and I've found a facility in Romania with a young female who needs rehoming within six months."

The silence that followed was so complete that Margaret wondered if the call had been dropped. She checked her phone screen to confirm they were still connected, then waited through what felt like the longest pause in the history of sibling communication. When Robert finally spoke, his voice had dropped to the careful, measured tone he used when dealing with clients who might be having mental health crises.

"Margaret, I think perhaps you should take some time off work. Maybe see someone to talk through whatever's been bothering you. This tiger idea, it's not rational. You live in a flat in the city center. You work in accounting. You don't know anything about caring for exotic animals." Robert's words came slowly, as if he were speaking to someone who might bolt at any sudden movement.

Margaret had anticipated this reaction, but hearing it articulated so clearly still stung. This was exactly why she'd avoided telling him - not because she thought he was wrong, but because she knew he was probably right, and she was determined to do it anyway. "I know it sounds mad, Robert, but I've done the research. It's legal with the proper licensing, and there are veterinarians who specialize in big cat care. I'd need to buy property outside the city, build proper enclosures, get insurance and permits. It's complicated but not impossible."

"Have you considered the cost? We're talking about hundreds of thousands of pounds, Margaret. Property, construction, ongoing care, insurance, licensing fees - and that's assuming you could even get approved, which is highly unlikely." Robert was warming to his argument now, marshaling facts the way he would challenge a witness in court. "And what happens when the tiger gets older, stronger, more dangerous? What happens if there's an accident, if someone gets hurt? You'd lose everything, face criminal charges, potentially worse."

Margaret stood at her kitchen window, watching office workers stream past on the pavement below, all of them heading toward jobs that provided steady paychecks and predictable futures. Six months ago, she would have been getting ready to join them, to spend another day adding columns of numbers and filing reports that no one would remember a week later. The tiger plan was insane, expensive, and probably doomed to failure, but it was also the first thing that had made her feel genuinely excited about getting up in the morning since she couldn't remember when.

"I might fail, Robert. I probably will fail. But I'm going to try anyway, because the alternative is spending the rest of my life wondering what would have happened if I'd been brave enough to attempt something extraordinary." Margaret surprised herself with the firmness in her voice, the absence of the apologetic tone she usually adopted when explaining her decisions to her brother.

Robert sighed heavily, and Margaret could picture him in his pristine office, straightening papers on his desk while contemplating how to handle his sister's apparent midlife crisis. "At least promise me you'll think this through properly. Don't make any irreversible decisions without talking to me first. Maybe we could meet for dinner this weekend and discuss the practical aspects more thoroughly."

Margaret agreed to dinner, knowing that Robert would spend the intervening days preparing arguments designed to talk her out of what he would undoubtedly characterize as temporary insanity. After ending the call, she finished her coffee and began getting ready for another day at Henderson & Associates, but her mind was already racing ahead to the evening's tasks. She had grant applications to complete, conservation organizations to contact, and property listings to research. For the first time in years, the prospect of leaving her flat felt like the beginning of an adventure rather than another step in an endless routine.

The Mackintosh Foundation occupied a restored Victorian townhouse in Edinburgh's New Town, its Georgian facades and manicured gardens suggesting the sort of old money philanthropy that Margaret had only read about in financial journals. She stood outside the wrought-iron gates at precisely ten minutes before her appointment, clutching a leather portfolio that contained what she hoped would be the most persuasive presentation of her life. Three weeks had passed since her conversation with Robert, three weeks of fevered preparation that had transformed her evening hours into a crash course in conservation biology, animal husbandry, and grant writing. Her brother had maintained a worried silence since their dinner the previous weekend, where his carefully prepared arguments had met with Margaret's equally carefully prepared responses, resulting in a stalemate that left both siblings frustrated and concerned.

Margaret had discovered the Mackintosh Foundation through a contact at the Scottish Wildlife Trust, a elderly volunteer named Mrs. Sinclair who had listened to Margaret's proposal with the kind of patient attention usually reserved for favorite grandchildren. The foundation, Mrs. Sinclair had explained, was established in the 1970s by Sir Duncan Mackintosh, a shipping magnate who had developed a passion for wildlife conservation after witnessing the destruction of tiger habitats during business trips to Southeast Asia. Since his death fifteen years ago, the foundation had been run by his daughter, Dr. Catherine Mackintosh, a former veterinarian who had abandoned private practice to focus on conservation work. More importantly, the foundation had a history of funding unconventional projects, including several private conservation efforts that traditional organizations had deemed too risky or innovative.

The receptionist, a young man with carefully styled hair and the sort of earnest demeanor that suggested recent university graduation, led Margaret through corridors lined with photographs of exotic wildlife and framed letters from conservation organizations around the world. Dr. Mackintosh's office occupied the entire top floor of the building, its tall windows offering panoramic views of Edinburgh's skyline while the walls displayed an eclectic collection of artifacts that spoke to a life spent traveling in service of wildlife preservation. Carved masks from Africa shared wall space with traditional textiles from India, while a massive mahogany desk was covered with reports, correspondence, and what appeared to be veterinary journals dating back several decades.

Dr. Catherine Mackintosh proved to be a woman in her early sixties with steel-grey hair pulled back in a practical bun and the sort of direct gaze that Margaret associated with people accustomed to making difficult decisions. She wore no makeup and minimal jewelry, but carried herself with the confidence of someone who had earned respect through competence rather than charm. When she spoke, her voice carried the slight Edinburgh accent of the educated classes, tempered by years of international travel and cross-cultural communication.

"Mrs. McLeod, I've read your preliminary proposal with considerable interest," Dr. Mackintosh began, gesturing for Margaret to take a seat in one of the leather chairs positioned in front of her desk.
